general.name: xsGetRandomNumber
general.desc: Returns a random number between 0 and 32766.

general.name: xsGetRandomNumberLH

params.name: low
params.desc: The lower bound for the range for the random number returned (included)

params.name: high
params.desc: The upper bound for the range for the random number returned (excluded)

general.desc: Returns a random number between `low` and `high`

general.name: xsGetRandomNumberMax

params.name: max
params.desc: The upper bound for the range for the random number returned (excluded)

general.desc: Returns a random number between 0 and `max`.

general.name: xsGetPlayerCivilization

params.name: playerNumber
params.desc: The player to get the civilization of

general.desc: Returns the civilization ID of the given player. Refer to the [Constant Reference](../constants/#3-civs "Jump to: XS Scriptin > Constant Reference > #3. Civs") for all the different civ IDs

general.name: xsGetPlayerInGame

params.name: playerNumber
params.desc: Check if this player is still alive

general.desc: Returns true if the player given is still alive, and false otherwise.

general.name: xsGetMapName

params.name: showFileExtension
params.desc: If this is set to true, then the returned name also contains the file extension

general.desc: Returns the name of the map currently being played.

general.name: xsGetMapID
general.desc: Returns the AI map type.

general.name: xsGetMapHeight
general.desc: Returns the Height of the map.

general.name: xsGetMapWidth
general.desc: Returns the Width of the map.

general.name: xsGetVictoryType
general.desc:
Returns an integer corresponding to different victory settings ingame. These are:

 0: Standard

1: Conquest

2: Time Limit

3: Score

4: Custom (scenarios only).

Last Man Standing returns 0 as well.

general.name: xsGetVictoryPlayer
general.desc: Returns the number of the player with the highest score in a normal game. Returns the number of the player who owns 5 relics or has a wonder if standard victory is enabled. In a game like KoTH, returns the number of the player who owns the monument.

general.name: xsGetVictoryPlayerForSecondaryGameMode
general.desc: Returns `1` when no secondary game mode is set. Returns the number of the player who owns the monument in game modes like KotH

general.name: xsGetVictoryTime
general.desc: For game modes like KoTH and other game modes where there is a timer on the screen, it returns the amount of time left in half seconds. meaning if the value returned is 799, it means there are 399.5s remaining. Returns `-1` otherwise

general.name: xsGetVictoryTimeForSecondaryGameMode
general.desc: For game modes like KoTH and other game modes where there is a timer on the screen, it returns the amount of time left in half seconds. meaning if the value returned is 799, it means there are 399.5s remaining. Returns `-1` otherwise

general.name: xsGetVictoryCondition
general.desc: Returns one of these constants: `cStandardVictory` `cWonderVictory` `cRelicVictory` `cKingOfTheHillVictory`

general.name: xsGetVictoryConditionForSecondaryGameMode
general.desc: Returns one of these constants: `cStandardVictory` `cWonderVictory` `cRelicVictory` `cKingOfTheHillVictory`

general.name: xsGetPlayerNumberOfTechs

params.name: playerNumber
params.desc: The player whoes technology count is being requested.

general.desc: Returns the number of technologies available to the player in the entire game.

general.name: xsObjectHasAction

params.name: playerID
params.desc: The player to check unit actions for

params.name: unitType
params.desc: The type of unit to check actions for. Values 9xx refer to classes

params.name: actionId
params.desc: The type of action to check for

params.name: targetPlayerID
params.desc: Check if the action is being performed on a unit (eg. attacking) of this player. Can use -1 to ignore this filter.

params.name: targetType
params.desc: Check if the action is being performed on a unit of this type. Values 9xx refer to classes. Can use -1 to ignore this filter.

params.name: targetUnitLevel
params.desc: Check if the action is being performed on a unit with this `Interface Kind` (look in the A.G.E.), eg: 3 - villagers, 4 - most military units. Can be used as an alternative to `targetType`. If both are used, will pick units that match either. Can use -1 to ignore this filter.

general.desc: Checks and returns if any unit matching the set filters of the given player has the specified action.

general.name: xsPlayerAttribute

params.name: playerNumber
params.desc: The player to get the resource of (0 for Gaia)

params.name: resourceID
params.desc: The ID of the resource to get the amount of

general.desc: Returns the amount the specified resource of the given player.

general.name: xsSetPlayerAttribute

params.name: playerNumber
params.desc: The player to set the resource of (0 for Gaia)

params.name: resourceID
params.desc: The ID of the resource to set the amount of

params.name: value
params.desc: The amount to set the resource to

general.desc: Sets the amount of the specified resource of the given player to the provided value.

general.name: xsTriggerVariable

params.name: variableID
params.desc: The ID of the variable to get the value of

general.desc: Returns the value of the variable of the given variable ID.

general.name: xsSetTriggerVariable

params.name: variableID
params.desc: The ID of the variable to set the value of

params.name: value
params.desc: The value to set the variable to

general.desc: Sets the value of the variable of the given variable ID to the provided value.

general.name: xsGetNumPlayers
general.desc: Returns the number of players in the game

general.name: xsChatData

params.name: message
params.desc: The message to display in chat

params.name: value
params.desc: This value is inserted in place of any `%d` used in the message of the function

general.desc: Shows the given message in the game chat

general.name: xsGetTime
general.desc: Returns the current game time - 1 in seconds

general.name: xsGetGameTime
general.desc: Returns the current game time in seconds

general.name: xsEffectAmount

params.name: effectID
params.desc: The ID of the effect to use

params.name: unitOrTechnologyID
params.desc: The ID of the unit or technology to effect

params.name: attributeOrOperation
params.desc: The attribute to modify or the operation to perform

params.name: value
params.desc: The value of the effect

params.name: playerNumber
params.desc: The player to apply the effect to. If unspecified, applies to all players except Gaia.

general.desc: Change the specified attribute of the specified unit or technology by the value for the specified player. For more information on this, check the [UserPatch]("Jump to: UserPatch NON EXISTENT") section of the guide

general.name: xsResearchTechnology

params.name: techID
params.desc: The technology ID to research.

params.name: force
params.desc: Force researching the tech even if it is not enabled. To force an unavailable tech, the argument `techAvailable` must be set to false

params.name: techAvailable
params.desc: This flag determines if it is required to check if a tech is available before researching it

params.name: playerNumber
params.desc: The player to research the technology for

general.desc: Returns a boolean based on whether the technology was researched or not.

general.name: xsGetObjectCount

params.name: playerId
params.desc: The player to get the object count for

params.name: id
params.desc: The ID of the object to get the count for

general.desc: Returns the number of currently alive objects with the given ID of the specified player

general.name: xsGetObjectCountTotal

params.name: playerId
params.desc: The player to get the object count for

params.name: id
params.desc: The ID of the object to get the count for

general.desc: Returns the number of currently alive/standing + queued/foundation objects with the given ID of the specified player

general.name: xsTaskAmount

params.name: taskFieldId
params.desc:
Specifies which property of the task to change (names correspond with A.G.E.):
    - 0: Work Value 1 (Task 155 - Quantity to mul/add to the attribute modified)
    - 1: Work Value 2 (Task 155 - Min number of units required to activate the effect. See Monaspa)
    - 2: Work Range
    - 3: Work Flag 2
    - 4: Search Wait Time (Task 155 - Attribute to modify. Only some attributes are supported: [Movement Speed](../../attributes/attributes/#5-movement-speed), [Attack](../../attributes/attributes/#9-attack), [Attack Reload Time](../../attributes/attributes/#10-attack-reload-time), [Work Rate](../../attributes/attributes/#13-work-rate), [Regeneration Rate](../../attributes/attributes/#109-regeneration-rate), [Conversion Chance Modifier](../../attributes/attributes/#113-conversion-chance-modifier), 116 - Melee Armor, 117 - Pierce Armor)
    - 5: Unused Flag (Task 155 - Combinable bitfield: 1 - Multiply instead of Add, 2 - Circular instead of Rectangular radius, 4 - Range indicator shown, 8 - Unused, 16 - Unused, 32 - Translucent)
    - 6: Target Diplomacy

params.name: value
params.desc: The value to set the task field to

general.desc: Sets the value of the given field of the global XS task struct to the provided value. See also [xsTask](./#531-xstask). It is recommended to always set all values before inserting or updating a task otherwise the insert/update might fail.

general.name: xsTask

params.name: unitId
params.desc: The unit to add the task to

params.name: actionType
params.desc: Task type. Eg.: 105 for heal, 155 for aura and etc. Look in the A.G.E.

params.name: targetUnitId
params.desc: Target unitId for the task if exists. Values 9xx refer to classes.

params.name: playerId
params.desc: The player to whose units the task will be inserted. If unspecified or -1, applies to all players except Gaia.

general.desc:
Adds a new (or edits an existing) task with the fields previously defined by calls to [xsTaskAmount](./#532-xstaskamount) for the specified unit at the end of the task list (see A.G.E.). If a task with the specified `actionType`, `unitId`, and `Search Wait Time` (set by `xsTaskAmount`) already exists, it is edited instead of a new one being added.

Note that `xsTaskAmount` modifies a global task struct which is re-used every time `#!cpp xsTask` is called (For non programmers, this is similar to filling out a form once (the calls to [xsTaskAmount](./#532-xstaskamount)) and then submitting multiple copies of it for different people)

general.name: xsRemoveTask

params.name: unitId
params.desc: Unit to remove the task from.

params.name: actionType
params.desc: Task type. Eg.: 105 for heal, 155 for aura and etc. Look in the A.G.E.

params.name: targetUnitId
params.desc: Target unitId for the task if exists. Values 9xx refer to classes.

params.name: playerId
params.desc: The player from whose units the task will be removed. If unspecified or -1, applies to all players except Gaia.

general.desc: Removes a task from a unit if the specified `actionType`, `unitId`, and `Search Wait Time` (set by [xsTaskAmount](./#532-xstaskamount)) match an existing task in a unit. No other fields are used for filtering (same as when [xsTask](./#531-xstask) edits instead of adding a new task)

Read/Write.name: xsCreateFile

params.name: append
params.desc: Default: `#!cpp true`. If set to `#!cpp false`, this will overwrite any existing file with the same name.

Read/Write.desc: Creates a new (or appends to an existing) `.xsdat` file with the same name as the RMS/scenario being played. After invoking this function, the writing functions can be used to write data to the file. Returns `#!cpp true` if the file was successfully created. In a multiplayer game a file is created for each player, and subsequent writes will be duplicated to each player.

Read/Write.name: xsOpenFile

params.name: filename
params.desc: The name of the file to open, without the `.xsdat` extension

Read/Write.desc: Opens an existing `.xsdat`file in read only mode. After invoking this function, the reading functions can be used to read data from the file. Returns `#!cpp true` if the file was successfully opened. In a multiplayer game, the file being read must exist for all players and contain the same data to avoid an out of sync error

Read/Write.name: xsWriteString

params.name: data
params.desc: The string to write

Read/Write.desc: Writes a string to the previously created `.xsdat` file. Causes an error if a file hasn't been opened before using. Returns `#!cpp true` if the string was successfully written. A string is written to the file in two parts, an unsigned 32 bit integer (indicates the length of the string) followed by that many bytes making up the actual characters of the string

Read/Write.name: xsWriteInt

params.name: data
params.desc: The integer to write

Read/Write.desc: Writes an integer to the previously created `.xsdat` file. Causes an error if a file hasn't been opened before using. Returns `#!cpp true` if the integer was successfully written. Integers are written as signed 32 bit numbers

Read/Write.name: xsWriteFloat

params.name: data
params.desc: The float value to write

Read/Write.desc: Writes a floating point number to the previously created `.xsdat` file. Causes an error if a file hasn't been opened before using. Returns `#!cpp true` if the floating point number was successfully written. Floats are written in the 32 bit IEEE 754 format

Read/Write.name: xsWriteVector

params.name: data
params.desc: The vector to write

Read/Write.desc: Writes a vector to the previously created `.xsdat` file. Causes an error if a file hasn't been opened before using. Returns `#!cpp true` if the vector was successfully written. Vectors are written as 3 consecutive floating point numbers, one for each coordinate.

Read/Write.name: xsReadString
Read/Write.desc: Reads and returns a string from the previously opened `.xsdat` file. Note that this function does not check if the value being read is actually meant to be a string, which means the value being read is bit casted into a string regardless of what it originally was. This function also moves the file position forward by 4 bytes + the amount of bytes in the length of the string

Read/Write.name: xsReadInt
Read/Write.desc: Reads and returns an integer from the previously opened `.xsdat` file. Note that this function does not check if the value being read is actually meant to be an integer, which means the value being read is bit casted into an integer regardless of what it originally was. This function also moves the file position forward by 4 bytes

Read/Write.name: xsReadFloat
Read/Write.desc: Reads and returns a float from the previously opened `.xsdat` file. Note that this function does not check if the value being read is actually meant to be a float, which means the value being read is bit casted into a float regardless of what it originally was. This function also moves the file position forward by 4 bytes

Read/Write.name: xsReadVector
Read/Write.desc: Reads and returns a vector from the previously opened `.xsdat` file. Note that this function does not check if the value being read is actually meant to be a vector, which means the value being read is bit casted into a vector regardless of what it originally was. This function also moves the file position forward by 12 bytes

Read/Write.name: xsSetFilePosition

params.name: byteOffset
params.desc: 0 indexed byte offset to determine which byte to read and return from the file

Read/Write.desc: Sets the byte (0-indexed) of the file that the next read function will start reading from.

Read/Write.name: xsOffsetFilePosition

params.name: dataType
params.desc: The [cOffset constants](../constants/#1-readwrite "Jump To: XS > Constant Reference > Read/Write Constants") can be used to specify the datatype used for the offset. Integers and floats are 4 bytes long, vectors are 12 bytes long and strings can be of variable length (specified by the 32 bit int preceeding the chars of the string)

params.name: forward
params.desc: Default: `#!cpp true`. Setting this to `#!cpp false` will make the file position move back

Read/Write.desc: Moves the file position forward (or backward) relative to the current file position, and by an amount of bytes equivalent to reading the given data type

Read/Write.name: xsCloseFile
Read/Write.desc: Close the currently opened or created file. Returns `#!cpp true` if the file was successfully closed

Read/Write.name: xsGetFilePosition
Read/Write.desc: Gets the byte (0-indexed) of the file that the next read function will start reading from.

Read/Write.name: xsGetDataTypeSize

params.name: type
params.desc: One of the `cOffsetXXX` constants may be used as a parameter

Read/Write.desc: Returns the number of bytes used to store a given type value.

Read/Write.name: xsGetFileSize
Read/Write.desc: Gets the size (in bytes) of the currently open file

AI Scripting.name: xsGetGoal

Functions With Seemingly No Practical Us.name: xsDumpArrays
Functions With Seemingly No Practical Us.desc: This function is supposed to blogs out all XS arrays. Currently, it does absolutely nothing.

Functions With Seemingly No Practical Us.name: xsGetContextPlayer
Functions With Seemingly No Practical Us.desc: Returns the current context player ID.

Functions With Seemingly No Practical Us.name: xsSetContextPlayer

params.name: playerNumber
params.desc: The player to set the context player to

Functions With Seemingly No Practical Us.desc: In other functions involving a `playerNumber` argument, the value of the context player is used if `-1` is passed as `playerNumber` to them. `xsEffectAmount` will use the value of the context player as its player if `-2` is passed to it as the player argument.

Functions With Seemingly No Practical Us.name: xsGetFunctionID

params.name: functionName
params.desc: The name of the function to get the hash of

Functions With Seemingly No Practical Us.desc: Returns the hash of a given function. This function has no practical application and is probably for internal usage only.

Functions With Seemingly No Practical Us.name: xsBreakPoint
Functions With Seemingly No Practical Us.desc: This function is meant to add a break point to the execution of XS code for debugging. This used to cause a crash in crash earlier versions of DE.

Functions With Seemingly No Practical Us.name: xsAddRuntimeEvent

params.name: runtimeName
params.desc: This is the name of the runtime to create the event in. This should be `"Random Map"` for RMS and `"Scenario Triggers"` for scenarios. Find which one to use in a general script by using the `#!cpp xsGetMapName(true)` [function](./#56-xsgetmapname "Jump To: Function Reference > xsGetMapName") and checking the extension. To use with an AI, set the runtime name to "Expert" and pass the player number as the arg

params.name: functionName
params.desc: This is the name of a user defined function that takes a single integer argument

params.name: functionArgument
params.desc: This is an integer argument that is passed to the function given to the argument `functionName` when this event runs.

Functions With Seemingly No Practical Us.desc: A runtime event is called after all the XS code has finished executing but before rules start executing. It calls the function `functionName` given to it with the `functionArgument` passed to it as a parameter. For programmers familiar with the terminology, this is basically a way to set a callback. It also returns true if the function name given to it exists, otherwise it returns false. Does not work with built-ins
